definitions.definition: to cause physical pain to somebody/yourself; to injure somebody/yourself
definitions.labels: (especially British English)(informal)(formal)(especially North American English)(British English)(especially British English)(North American English)(formal)(British English)(North American English)

examples.text: He hurt his back playing squash.
Strong light hurts my eyes.
Did you hurt yourself?
Stop it. You're hurting me.
No one was **seriously hurt** in the accident.
My back is really hurting me today.
My shoes hurt—they're too tight.
I was shaken, but not actually hurt.
She fell and hurt her leg quite badly.

definitions.sensetop: it hurts when/if…it hurts to do something

examples.text: My feet hurt.
My head hurts.
Ouch! That hurt!
It hurts when I bend my knee.
It hurts if I move my neck.
It hurts to breathe.
My ankle still hurts quite badly.
Ouch! It really hurts.
I knew it was going to hurt—but not that much!
Does it hurt a lot?

definitions.definition: to make somebody unhappy or upset
definitions.sensetop: hurt somebody/somethingit hurts to do somethingit hurts somebody to do something

examples.text: What **really hurt** was that he never answered my calls.
I'm sorry, I didn't mean to hurt you.
I didn't want to **hurt his feelings**.
It always hurts to lose, especially in the final.
It hurt me to think that he would lie to me.
examples.contextForm: it hurts somebody to do something

examples.text: They never told me why and that really hurt.
Are you deliberately trying to hurt me?
Her remarks hurt him deeply.
I never meant to hurt anyone.
Why would I want to hurt her?
I know you're hurting and I want to help you.

definitions.definition: to have a bad effect on somebody/something

examples.text: Hard work never hurt anyone.
Many people on low incomes will be hurt by the government's plans.
High interest rates are hurting the local economy.

definitions.definition: to be in a difficult situation because you need something, especially money

examples.text: His campaign is already hurting for money.

definitions.definition: to affect somebody where they will feel it most
used to say that somebody should do a particular thing

examples.text: It wouldn't hurt you to help with the housework occasionally.

definitions.definition: to be kind and gentle and unwilling to cause unhappiness

wordOrigin: Middle English (originally in the senses ‘ to strike’ and ‘a blow’): from Old French hurter (verb), hurt (noun), perhaps ultimately of Germanic origin.
